title: The Words of Agur
shortSummary: Proverbs 30 presents the sayings of Agur, a wise man who humbly acknowledges his own limitations and seeks God's provision and guidance. The chapter contains profound reflections on human folly, the nature of God’s word, and observations about life’s mysteries and moral warnings. It encourages trust in God's purity and wisdom while warning against pride, falsehood, and unrighteous behavior.
timeline: c. 10th century BC - Period of the Proverbs, attributed to Solomon and other wise men including Agur

keyCharacters.name: Agur the son of Jakeh
keyCharacters.description: The primary speaker of this chapter, a wise man who delivers a prophecy and reflections on wisdom, human limitations, and divine truth.

keyCharacters.name: Ithiel
keyCharacters.description: One of the individuals to whom Agur directs his words, possibly a student or companion.

keyCharacters.name: Ucal
keyCharacters.description: Another individual addressed by Agur, likely a student or listener of his teachings.

definitions.definition: Lacking understanding or intelligence; foolish or senseless, as used by Agur to describe himself.
Empty or worthless things; often refers to things without lasting value or truth.
A leech that attaches to horses, used metaphorically for insatiable greed.
Small rock-dwelling animals, often translated as hyraxes, noted for their wisdom in making homes in rocks.

outline.heading: Agur’s Humble Confession and Divine Inquiry
outline.description: Agur begins by acknowledging his own lack of wisdom and understanding, then poses rhetorical questions about God's sovereignty and the mysteries of creation, emphasizing human limitation in comprehending divine matters.

outline.heading: The Purity of God's Word and a Prayer for Provision
outline.description: Agur affirms the purity and trustworthiness of God's word, warns against adding to it, and prays for neither poverty nor riches, seeking a balanced life that fosters dependence on God.

outline.heading: Warnings Against Ungodly Generations
outline.description: This section describes various sinful behaviors and attitudes prevalent in certain generations, including disrespect to parents, pride, greed, and deceit, along with the consequences of such conduct.

outline.heading: The Wonders and Mysteries of Life
outline.description: Agur reflects on four things that are too wonderful to understand, highlighting the inscrutable ways of nature and human relationships, including the deceptive nature of the adulterous woman.

outline.heading: Earth’s Disturbing Conditions and Examples of Wisdom in Nature
outline.description: The chapter lists conditions that cause unrest on earth and showcases four small creatures that demonstrate wisdom, as well as four admirable things in their movement, illustrating God’s design and order.

outline.heading: A Final Exhortation Against Pride and Wrath
outline.description: Agur concludes with a warning against pride and evil thoughts, urging self-control and illustrating how anger inevitably leads to conflict.

application: Humbly recognize your limitations and seek God’s wisdom rather than relying on your own understanding.
Trust in the purity and sufficiency of God’s Word; avoid adding to or subtracting from it in doctrine or practice.
Pray for contentment with God’s provision, asking neither for poverty nor riches to keep your heart faithful.
Respect and honor your parents and avoid attitudes of pride, greed, and deceit that lead to destruction.

keyVerses.text: Every word of God is pure: he is a shield unto them that put their trust in him.
keyVerses.significance: This verse affirms the absolute purity and trustworthiness of God's Word and His protection over those who trust Him.

keyVerses.text: Remove far from me vanity and lies : give me neither poverty nor riches; feed me with food convenient for me:
keyVerses.significance: A prayer for balanced provision that fosters dependence on God and guards against the spiritual dangers of both wealth and poverty.

keyVerses.text: There be three things which are too wonderful for me, yea, four which I know not:
keyVerses.significance: Highlights the mystery and wonder of God's creation, encouraging humility in the face of divine wisdom beyond human understanding.

keyVerses.text: Surely the churning of milk bringeth forth butter, and the wringing of the nose bringeth forth blood: so the forcing of wrath bringeth forth strife.
keyVerses.significance: A vivid illustration of how uncontrolled anger inevitably leads to conflict, urging believers to practice self-control.
